title: Were Jews living in pre-Israel Palestine 'Palestinians', and if so, what were Palestinians called? - Quora

response.answer_text: If you read historical documents talking about Palestine such as old travelogues, the British White Papers, the Peel Report, reports to the UN, contemporary news reports from archives etc., you will generally see references to “Palestinian Jews” and “Palestinian Arabs” or to “Jews” and “Arabs” (for short.) What you will not see is references to “Jews” and “Palestinians” (when the two groups are being discussed together) with the term “Palestinian” referring solely to the Arab residents. For example, UNGA 181 proposed ‘a Jewish state’ and ‘an Arab state’ not ‘a Jewish state’ and ‘a Palestinian state’. [1] . UNSC 242, passed in 1967, refers to “ territories occupied in the recent conflict” by Israel, not to ‘Occupied Palestinian Territories”[2] Even the PLO’s original charter refers to “The Palestinian Arab people” - that qualifier being necessary because when the charter was written (in 1964) ‘Palestinian’ was not synonymous with ‘Arab’ (and it renounced any claim to sovereignty over the West Bank and Gaza as well, since those areas were still in Jordanian and Egyptian hands.)[3] While it is true, as one of the answers below notes, that both Jews and Arabs could be referred to as Palestinians (because both groups became citizens of Mandate for Palestine after 1920) the word ‘Palestinian’ (when used alone without some other context qualifying it) generally referred to Jews. This was because, although Palestine had previously been the name of a geographical area belonging to the Ottoman Empire, in 1920 the term ‘Palestine’ became associated with the polity established by the British Mandate for Palestine (the mandate of which was to create a Jewish National Home[4] ). Therefore the label of ‘Palestinian’ was rejected by many Arabs at the time as an insult because of its association with Zionism. For example, Auni Bey Abdul-Hadi testified to British Peel Commission, 1937: “There is no such country as Palestine. ‘Palestine’ is a term the Zionists invented. There is no Palestine in the Bible. Our country was for centuries part of Syria. ‘Palestine’ is alien to us. It is the Zionists who introduced it” [5] Otherwise there’s no explaining the following:  This headline in the NY Times makes NO sense unless ‘Palestinian’ referred primarily to Jews. Nor would this one:  (They objected because the issuing bank, the Anglo-Palestine Bank was a Jewish bank, and the Hebrew writing on the bills said “Land of Israel”)  Nor do the following references to the flag of Palestine in old books* make any sense otherwise:   *See this comment for a video about the book [6] The Feisal Weizmann agreement of 1919 referred to ‘the Arab State and Palestine’ and it is clear that the document is agreeing that ‘the Arab State’ is to be the state of ‘the Arab People’ and Palestine is to be the state of ‘the Jewish People’.   If “Palestinian’ had meant ‘Arab’, Emir Faisal and Weizmann would have been agreeing on the establishment of ‘the Arab state’ and ‘another Arab state’ - which makes no sense. In general Arabs in Palestine were called Arabs.   Notice the above doesn’t say “Palestine for the Palestinians”. Further evidence can be found by searching old books and news archives. If “Palestinians” was a term that for centuries had meant ‘the Palestinian people’ (as we understood it today), references to “Palestinians” should show up in old books before the creation of the Mandate. They do not, as this Google search of books shows.  Searches of old newspaper archives produce similar results. It was not until the 1960s (after the PLO was founded and after Israel captured the West Bank) that the term ‘Palestinian’ became associated almost exclusively with Arabs. Footnotes[1] http://www.mfa.gov.il/mfa/foreignpolicy/peace/guide/pages/un%20general%20assembly%20resolution%20181.aspx (http://www.mfa.gov.il/mfa/foreignpolicy/peace/guide/pages/un%20general%20assembly%20resolution%20181.aspx)[2] S/RES/242 (1967) of 22 November 1967[3] Permanent Observer Mission of the State of Palestine to the United Nations[4] The Palestine Mandate[5] https://books.google.co.il/books?dq=***There+is+no+such+country+as+Palestine.+%E2%80%98Palestine%E2%80%99+is+a+term+the+Zionists&hl=en&id=5e8fUmqEuNIC&lpg=PA142&ots=CeSgA-tNXL&pg=PA142&sa=X&sig=QJo7UFuI-NjKS3J04WpCf8acZnw&source=bl&ved=0ahUKEwiByt23kr_aAhUhMewKHb_MBgkQ6AEIQDAD#v=onepage&q=***There%20is%20no%20such%20country%20as%20Palestine.%20%E2%80%98Palestine%E2%80%99%20is%20a%20term%20the%20Zionists&f=false[6] https://www.quora.com/Were-Jews-living-in-pre-Israel-Palestine-Palestinians-and-if-so-what-were-Palestinians-called/answer/Gail-Ellis-2/comment/60904761

There is the idea of “Palestinian-Jews” and its definition changes according to who says it and why. “Palestine” in that context can mean two things: a land and a nation. Most Jews before 1948 saw “Palestine” as just a foreign name for “Israel”. When Jews heard “Palestine”, they thought about “The Land of Israel”, this is just another name to “our land”. Before Zionism, there was the term “Yehudei Eretz Yisrael” which simply means “Jews of the Land of Israel” which refers to Jews who live in the Land of Israel. So “Palestinian Jews” may simply refer to “Jews who live in Palestine” which as mentioned above, is just another name for the “Land of Israel” In the other context, “Palestinian Jews” means “Jews who are members of the Palestinian nation”. You can find no more than a handful of those. The Palestinian Liberation Organization refers to the Jews who lived in Palestine before Zionism as members of the Palestinian nation, but those Jews today are already mixed with the Jewish migrants and are Zionist just like the migrants. Pure pre-Zionism, Palestinian-Jews barely exist today. The first use of “Palestinian” to refer to a nation was made in the early 20th century mainly by Christian Arabs in Palestine and was rarely used until it gradually grew in popularity until 1948 and even then, not all of the Arabs in Palestine saw themselves as Palestinians most would self identify as Southern Syrians, or simply Arabs). The “Palestinian Nation” is a very problematic term. Before 1968, the “Palestinians” were only those who lived in the territories that were captured by Israel in 1948. The Arabs who lived in the West Bank were considered Jordanians while those in the Gaza Strip were simply called “Arabs” (Gaza between 1949–1967 was under Egyptian military rule). When Israel occupied the West Bank and Gaza Strip in 1967, a year later, suddenly, the PLO decided that “Palestinians” now include the West Bank and the Gaza Strip. There is a known saying, “Why is it that on June 4, 1967 I was a Jordanian and overnight I became a ‘Palestinian’?” - Walid Shoebat. The PLO refer to Israeli-Arabs as Palestinians as well, but only in recent years, some Israeli-Arabs started calling themselves Palestinians. Today only 20% of the Israeli-Arabs refer to themselves as “Palestinian Arabs” while other 40% prefer “Palestinian citizens of Israel” and the rest call themselves “Arab citizens of Israel”.
